quest_title: The vectors a and b are non-collinear. The value of x for which the vectors \(c=(x-2)\, a+b\) and \(d=(2x+1)\, a-b\) are collinear, is
explanation_txt:
Since \(c=(x-2)a+b\) and \(d=(2x+1)a-b\) are collinear, therefore \(c=\lambda d\)

\[\Rightarrow (x-2)a+b=\lambda (2x+1)a-\lambda b\]

or \([(x-2)-\lambda (2x+1)]a+(\lambda +1)b=0\)

\[(x-2)-\lambda (2x+1)=0,\lambda +1=0\]

\(({\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \, \, \, a,\, b\) are linearly independent)

\[\Rightarrow x-2+2x+1=0\Rightarrow x=\cfrac{1}{3} .\]

explanation_plain_text:

or

quest_title: An object with a mass 10 kg moves at a constant velocity of 10 m/sec. A constant force then acts for 4 second on the object and gives it a speed of 2 m/sec in opposite direction. The acceleration produced in it, is

quest_title: Two putty balls of equal mass moving with equal velocity in mutually perpendicular directions, stick together after collision. If the balls were initially moving with a velocity of \(45 \sqrt { 2 } \mathrm { ms } ^ { - 1 }\) each, the velocity of their combined mass after collision is
explanation_txt:
Initial momentum

\(\vec { P } = m 45 \sqrt { 2 } \hat { i } + m 45 \sqrt { 2 } \hat { j } \Rightarrow | \vec { P } | = m \times 90\)

Final momentum \(2 m \times V\)

By conservation of momentum \(2 m \times V = m \times 90\)

\(\therefore\) V = 45 m/s
question_plain_title: Two putty balls of equal mass moving with equal velocity in mutually perpendicular directions, stick together after collision. If the balls were initially moving with a velocity of each, the velocity of their combined mass after collision is
explanation_plain_text:
Initial momentum

Final momentum

By conservation of momentum

V = 45 m/s

quest_title: A force of 750 N is applied on a block of mass 102 kg to prevent it from sliding on a plane with inclination 30\(^{\circ}\) with the horizontal. If the coefficient of static and kinetic friction between the block and plane are 0.4 and 0.3 respectively, then frictional force acting on the block is
explanation_txt:
Limiting force of friction for 20 kg

\(\begin{aligned} F_{f}=\mu_{s} m g \cos \theta=& 0.4 \times 1020 \times \cos 30 \\ &=353.3 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}\)

For equilibrium,

\(\begin{aligned} F &=m g \sin \theta+F_{f} \\ \Rightarrow F_{f} &=F-m g \sin \theta \\ &=750-1020 \times \sin 30 \\ &=750-1020 \times \cfrac{1}{2}=240 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A force of 750 N is applied on a block of mass 102 kg to prevent it from sliding on a plane with inclination 30 with the horizontal. If the coefficient of static and kinetic friction between the block and plane are 0.4 and 0.3 respectively, then frictional force acting on the block is
explanation_plain_text:
Limiting force of friction for 20 kg

For equilibrium,

quest_title: The bulk modulus of rubber is 9.8\(\times\)10\({}^{8}\)N/m\({}^{2}\). The depth to which a rubber ball is taken in a lake so that it's volume decreased by 0.1% is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{B}=\cfrac{P V}{-\cfrac{\mathrm{dv}}{\mathrm{v}}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \rho=9.8 \times 10^{8} \times \cfrac{0.1}{100}\)
\(\Rightarrow \rho \mathrm{gh}=9.8 \times 10^{5}\)
\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{h}=\cfrac{9.8 \times 10^{5}}{9.8 \times 10^{3}}=100 \, m\)

quest_title: Two gases of equal mass are in thermal equilibrium. If \(P_{a} ,\, P_{b} \) and \(V_{a} \) and \(V_{b} \) are their respective pressures and volumes, then which relation is true
explanation_txt:
Boyle's law states that at a constant temperature, the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume.

i.e. \(P\propto \cfrac{1}{V}\)

i.e. \(PV=\text{const}\)

i.e. \(P_{a} V_{a} =P_{b} V_{b} \)

quest_title: Which source is associated with a line emission spectrum?
explanation_txt:
Neon light is produced when electron falls down from higher orbit to lower orbit in Neon atoms. This de-excitation of electrons produces light of specific frequency corresponding to the energy level difference between the orbits. Therefore, light emission in neon street light is emission line spectrum of Neon atom.

Electric fire and Sun produce light of all wavelength i.e. continuous spectrum as given by planck distribution.

Red traffic light is generally composed of Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) and light is produced when electrons combine with holes which is also a continuous spectrum in a given range of wavelength. This can be explained from the following fact:

Semiconductor has a range of valence potential called valence band (energy level of non conducting electrons) and also a range of conduction potential called conduction band (energy level of conducting electrons). So, when an electron jumps from conduction band to valence band, light of wavelength with energy corresponding to that particular energy difference is produced. This energy difference is not same for all electrons combining with holes as conduction and valence state exists in a range.
question_plain_title: Which source is associated with a line emission spectrum?
explanation_plain_text:
Neon light is produced when electron falls down from higher orbit to lower orbit in Neon atoms. This de-excitation of electrons produces light of specific frequency corresponding to the energy level difference between the orbits. Therefore, light emission in neon street light is emission line spectrum of Neon atom.

Electric fire and Sun produce light of all wavelength i.e. continuous spectrum as given by planck distribution.

Red traffic light is generally composed of Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) and light is produced when electrons combine with holes which is also a continuous spectrum in a given range of wavelength. This can be explained from the following fact:

Semiconductor has a range of valence potential called valence band (energy level of non conducting electrons) and also a range of conduction potential called conduction band (energy level of conducting electrons). So, when an electron jumps from conduction band to valence band, light of wavelength with energy corresponding to that particular energy difference is produced. This energy difference is not same for all electrons combining with holes as conduction and valence state exists in a range.

quest_title: The number of arrangements of the letters of the word BANANA in which two N's do not appear adjacently is:
explanation_txt: Required number of arrangements = (Total number of arrangements) - (Number of arrangements in which N'\(\textit{s}\) are together) \[=\cfrac{6!}{2!\, \, \times \, \, 3!} -\cfrac{5!}{3!} =60-20=40.\]

quest_title: A metal obtained directly by roasting of its sulphide ore is
explanation_txt:
When conc. \(HgS\) ore is roasted , reaction occurs are :

\[HgS+O_{2} \stackrel{773-873K}{\longrightarrow} Hg+SO_{2} \]

At this temperature, mercury vaporises and the vapours are condensed to the liquid metal. Mercury so obtained is about 99.7\% pure.

\(=\cfrac{30}{4} \times 3=22.5 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: A equiconvex lens of glass is placed on horizontal plane mirror. The image of pin at 1m coincides with its image. If liquid is placed between lens & mirror then pin has to be raised by 0.55m for coincidence to occur. The refractive index of liquid is
explanation_txt:
For lens
\(\mathrm{F}_{1}=1 \mathrm{m}=100 \mathrm{cm}\)
For combined
\(\mathrm{F}=1.55 \mathrm{m}=155 \mathrm{cm}\)
Now, \(\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{1}}=(\mu-1) \cfrac{2}{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{R}=(1.5-1) \times 2 \times 100=100 \mathrm{cm}\)

Here, \(\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{F}}=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{1}}+\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{2}}\)
\(\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{2}}=\cfrac{1}{155}-\cfrac{1}{100}\)
or, \(\mathrm{f}_{2}=\cfrac{15500}{-55}=\cfrac{-3100}{11} \mathrm{cm}\)
Now, \(\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{2}}=\left(\mu_{l}-1\right)\left(-\cfrac{1}{100}\right)\)
or, \(\mu_{l}=1+\cfrac{11}{31}=1.35\)

quest_title: A length \(\textit{L}\) of wire carries a steady current \(\textit{I}\). It is bent first to form a circular plane coil of one turn. The same length is now bent more sharply to give a double loop of smaller radius. The magnetic field at the centre caused by the same current is
explanation_txt:
Magnetic field at the centre of current carrying coil is given by

\(B=\cfrac{\mu _{0} }{4\pi } \cdot \cfrac{2\pi Ni}{r} \)

\(\Rightarrow\)\(B\propto \cfrac{N}{r} \)

\(\Rightarrow\)\(\cfrac{B_{1} }{B_{2} } =\cfrac{N_{1} }{N_{ 2} } \times \cfrac{r_{2} }{r_{1} } \).

The following figure shows that single turn coil changes to double turn coil.

\[\Rightarrow\cfrac{B_{1}}{B_{2} } =\cfrac{1}{2} \times \cfrac{r/2}{r} =\cfrac{1}{4} \Rightarrow B_{2} =4B\]

Short trick : For such type of problems remember \(B_{2} =n^{2} B_{1} \)

quest_title: What will happen if at equilibrium some \(\text{H\(_{2}\)(g)}\) is added in the gaseous reaction ? \(\text{H\(_{2}\)(g)}\) + \(\text{I\(_{2}\)}\) (g)   \(\leftrightharpoons\) 2HI (g)
ans1_txt: The yield of the product will be decreased
ans2_txt: The yield of the product will be increased
ans3_txt: The yield of the product will be unaffected
ans4_txt: The equilibrium will never be regained
explanation_txt:
According to Le-Chateliar's principle, the reaction procees towards decreased concentration.

So, on addition of \(H_2\) concentration of reactants is more than products [at equilibrium]. Hence, more product is yielded.
question_plain_title: What will happen if at equilibrium some is added in the gaseous reaction ? + (g) 2HI (g)
explanation_plain_text:
According to Le-Chateliar's principle, the reaction procees towards decreased concentration.

So, on addition of concentration of reactants is more than products [at equilibrium]. Hence, more product is yielded.
ans1_plain_text: The yield of the product will be decreased
ans2_plain_text: The yield of the product will be increased
ans3_plain_text: The yield of the product will be unaffected
ans4_plain_text: The equilibrium will never be regained

quest_title: The frequency of whistle of an engine is observed to drop from 600 to 540 as train passes the stationary observer. What is the speed of engine?(speed sound is 340m/s)
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{f}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{f}^{\prime \prime}}=\cfrac{v}{v-v_{\mathrm{s}}} \times \cfrac{v+v_{\mathrm{s}}}{v}\)
or, \(\cfrac{600}{540}=\cfrac{340+v_{\mathrm{s}}}{340-v_{\mathrm{s}}}\)
or, \(3400-10 v_{\mathrm{s}}=340 \times 9+9 v_{\mathrm{s}}\)
or, \(v_{\mathrm{s}}=\cfrac{340}{19}=17.9 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\)

quest_title: In the following atoms and moleculates for the transition from \(\textit{n= }\)2 to \(\textit{ n = }\)1, the spectral line of minimum wavelength will be produced by
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{1}{\lambda } =RZ^{2} \left(\cfrac{1}{1^{2} } -\cfrac{1}{2^{2} } \right)\)

Here, \(\lambda \propto Z^{2}\) where \(Z\) is atomic number.

In the above options, atom having highest atomic number is Di-ionized lithium which is 3.

quest_title:
What is the effect of halving the pressure by doubling the volume on the following system at 500°C

\(H _ { 2 ( g ) } + I _ { 2 ( g ) } = 2 H LI_ { ( g ) }\)
explanation_txt:
We know that

\(P V = n R T\)

\(P\) become \(\cfrac { 1 } { 2 } P \& V\) bcome 2\(V\) so

\(\cfrac { 1 } { 2 } P \times 2 V = P V = n R T\)

So there is no effect in equation.

quest_title: Domain of the function \( \sqrt {\log \left \{ \left( 5 x - x ^ { 2 } \right) / 6 \right \} } \) is
explanation_txt:
\( \log \left\{ \cfrac { 5 x - x ^ { 2 } } { 6 } \right\} \geq 0 \Rightarrow \cfrac { 5 x - x ^ { 2 } } { 6 } \geq 1 \text { or } x ^ { 2 } - 5 x + 6 \leq 0 \)

\(( x - 2 ) ( x - 3 ) \leq 0\)

Hence \( 2 \le x \le 3 \)

NOTE:

\( (x-a)(x-b)(x-c) .... \) is greater or less than zero alternatively for intervals \( (-\infty,a) , (a,b), (b,c) , .... \) . For \( (x-2)(x-3) \), the intervals are \( (-\infty,2), (2,3) \) and \( (3,\infty ) \). Since the quadratic is positive for \( x < 2 \) it is negative in \( (2,3) \) and positive in \( (3, \infty) \)

quest_title: Which of the following is the strongest base?
explanation_txt:
\(CH_4\) is the weak acid. So its conjugate base \(CH_3^-\) is a strong base.

Other options are conjugate bases of relatively stronger acids.

explanation_txt:
\[T_{5} =ar^{4} =\cfrac{1}{3} \quad \quad \quad \quad (i) \]

\[T_{9} =ar^{8} =\cfrac{16}{243} \quad \quad \quad (ii)\]

Solving (i) and (ii), we get \(r=\cfrac{2}{3} \) and \(a=\cfrac{27}{16} \)

Now \(4^{th} \) term \[=ar^{3} =\cfrac{3^{3} }{2^{4} } .\cfrac{2^{3} }{3^{3} } =\cfrac{1}{2} \].
